Matt,

I would want your #11, I've been looking for it for some time, but y=
our
prices! Enough to make a predatory bookseller blush! Even the last copy=
 Mike
Y. (historian333) sold on eBay only went for $70 or so. (I missed see=
ing the
auction until it was over.)

As someone who, as of today, officiall=
y will be making my living selling
books, I am comforted by your prices - I=
 have many of the same titles - and
do hope you get them, it bodes well for=
 my business if you do.

Let me know if there is something we can work out,=
 even a trade for
something you are looking for ...

Craig L. Harris - Rare=
 Books
Bridge of Dreams, LLC

From: Matthew E. =

Subject: =
[nihontostudy] Crass Commercial Message, books and sword for sale.


Gang, =
I have decided to start the new year off by selling part of my
treasured bo=
ok collection, as well as the first sword I ever bought. Take a
moment to l=
ook this post over, some of these items are pretty hard to come
by these da=
ys. Free shipping to list members within Europe, 50% off shipping
to all ot=
hers. Extensive descriptions and pix available on request.
 
For Sale Books=
:
 
1. Japanese Swords & Sword Furniture in the Museum of Fine Arts Boston =
by
Morihiro Ogawa 1987. Hardback. This is a big heavy book that is quite ra=
re
now. Over 400 items listed in 423 pages. Lots of juyo quality stuff, mak=
ing
this a super reference book. Very good copy with very good dustjacket. =
Some
slight fading to the spine (dj) and some very small bumps only, otherw=
ise
perfect. Comes with separate glossery in mint condition. Asking $450
 
=
2. The Armour book in Honcho-Gunkiko by Arai Hakuseki 1964. Hardback. Rare
=
reference book. Very good condition, with only one very small tear to the
b=
ack of the dustjacket and priceclipped. Comes with protective brodart cover=

for the dj. Asking $200
 
3. The Hartman Collection of Japanese metalwork =
by Christie's, Mason and
Woods Ltd 1976. Published as a hardback with no du=
stjacket this book is in
very good condition also. Only slight fading to th=
e spine, otherwise
perfect. Comes with original errata and list of estimate=
s (loose).
Unfortunately no list of prices realised. A definate must have f=
or any
serious tsuba or kodogu collector, the collection of tsuba within is=
 simply
stunning. Asking $150
 
4. Masterpieces of the R. B. Caldwell colle=
ction of Japanese Sword Fittings
by Patrick Syz 1994. Hardback. One very ti=
ny crease to the top of the
dustjacket (hardly noticeable), otherwise absol=
utely mint. Comes with
protective brodart cover for the dj. Asking $200
 
5=
. The Arts of the Japanese Sword by B.W. Robinson. First edition, 1961.
Har=
dback. The book that every novice sword collector should have in his /
her =
collection. Very good condition, but no dustjacket. Some small scratches
to=
 the boards and minor bumping in the corners. Asking $125
 
6. Nippon-To Th=
e Japanese Sword by Inami Hakusui 1948. Hardback. An absolute
Classic, this=
 was the first English reference book written by a noted
Japanese expert. I=
n super condition, this book is a treasure to behold. One
small tear to the=
 dustjacket next to the spine only. No fading, no creases,
nothing. The boo=
k looks like it was published yesterday ! Interesting little
vintage pamphl=
et from the Japan Sword Co selling kitchen knives inside.
Comes with protec=
tive brodart cover for the dj. Asking $250
 
7. Early Japanese Sword Guards=
; Sukashi Tsuba, by Masayuki Sasano 1972.
Hardback. Classic reference book =
on sukashi tsuba this usually retails in
the $225 - 300 range depending on =
condition. Hoever this example is ex
libris and has the usual library stamp=
s inside. When it was in the library
the dustjacket was stuck to the inside=
 of the book(!). This has since been
remedied and the dustjacket is now loo=
se and comes in a protective brodart
cover but you can still see where it u=
sed to be stuck on. Otherwise in good
- very good condition. Asking $175 
 =

8. The Carlo Monzino Collection of Japanese Sword Fittings and Swords by
S=
otheby's 1996. Wonderful hardback auction catalog in mint condition. 122
pa=
ges of outstanding pieces. Asking $60
 
9. Japanese Master Swordsmiths: The=
 Gassan Tradition by The Museum of Fine
Arts, Boston 1989. Softcover in ver=
y fine condition. Must have reference for
any Gassan enthousiast. Asking $7=
5
 
10. Tosogu, Treasure of the Samurai by Sarzi-Amade Limited, 1991. Scarc=
e
catalog full of tsuba and other sword fittings, very lavishly illustrated=
.
In extremely good condition and very hard to come by. This is recommended=

for any kodogu lover. Comes with protective brodart cover for the dj. Aski=
ng
$125
 
11. Tsuba II: Returned Tsuba from Europe, by Inami Tomihiko. Hard=
back. This
is the second of a set of two describing various tsuba that were=
 returned
from Germany and Europe to Japan. Both are very hard to find. An =
interesting
book with 200 tsuba illustrated in this volume, most in b/w but=
 also quite a
few in color. Be warned this book is in Japanese though! Extr=
emely good
condition all round. Comes with protective brodart cover for the=
 dj. Asking
$100
 
12. Illustrated catalogues of Tokyo National Museum Swor=
d guard(s) by Tokyo
National Museum, 1979. Hardback. Another scarce / rare =
book illustrating 542
tsubas in the Tokyo National Museum.  Black and white=
 pictures
unfortunately, but still a must have reference for any serious ts=
uba
collector. I saw one copy in tatty condition sell on ebay last year for=

something like $300 (!). This copy is in very good to fine condition. Come=
s
with protective brodart cover for the dj. Asking $175
 
 
Right and now o=
n to the sword that I have for sale. This Nambokucho (14th
century) sword w=
as purchased last year from Aoi Arts in Japan. It comes with
fairly recent =
NBTHK Tokubetsu Hozon papers, a professional oshigata done at
Aoi Arts and =
their own menu shaped certificate describing the sword and
stating that it =
was then valued at 1,2 million yen. The sword is in a
shirasaya, no koshira=
e and is in excellent polish. I was toying with the
idea of submitting it t=
o Juyo Shinsa, but have so far not got round to it. I
don't know if it woul=
d stand a chance of going Juyo, but I think that it
should be submitted if =
only just for the experience which would be very
educational in my opinion.=
 It is attributed to the Nakajima Rai school which
seems to be pretty darn =
rare. At least this is the only one I have ever
seen. Below is the info exa=
ctly as on the Aoi Arts certificate.
 
'We certify the following Katana is =
genuine. Detail, Katana: the NBTHK
Tokubetsu-hozon token. 
Signature: Unsig=
ned, attributed to Nakajima-Rai. The blade is polished, in a
shirasaya. Bla=
de length: 62.7 cm or 24.69 inches.
Sori: 1.0 cm or 0.39 inch.
Width at the=
 hamachi: 2.98cm or 1.17 inches.
Width at the yokote: 2.11 cm or 0.83 inch.=

Thickness at the hamachi: 0.74 cm or 0.29 inch.
Era: Nambokucho-period. 14=
th century. 
 
Shape: A shinogi-zukuri katana. Broadish blade has plenty th=
ickness and the
point is O-kissaki.
Jitetsu: Small mokume is combined with =
small itame-hada. Fine jitetsu bears
delicate jinie.
Hamon: Nie-deki. Naka-=
suguha hamon goes with ashi, yo, kinsuji and
sunagashi.
Boshi: Niju-ba turn=
s back roundly on the front. 
 
A glance at this sword shows that clearly R=
ai School tradition. Acceptable
o-hada appears about six inches above the h=
amachi. Superb jitetsu and
sensitive works on the ha are the point of appre=
ciation. 1,200,000 Yen.' 
 
I still have the original Aoi Arts pictures tha=
t can be sent on request.
Asking $12,500. 
 
 
 
Thanks for taking the time=
 to read all this and let me know if I can be of
any further help or if any=
 of you want pix or more detailed descriptions.
